comment_text.mn150:1.2: We travel with the Buddha to several “villages of the Kosalan brahmins”, but this is the only recorded visit to Nagaravinda. The name seems to mean “mountain-lotus” (naga = “mountain”, aravinda = “lotus”). Sāvatthī lies only fifty kilometres south of the Himalayan foothills.
comment_text.mn150:4.1: This is an unusual framing, as usually the Buddha refers to wanderers of another religion when speaking with mendicants. The parallel simply says “other people” (SA 280 at T ii 76c8). Again, the fact that the villagers have diverse responses to the Buddha shows that they are not all Buddhists, and hence it would be out of character for the Buddha to assume otherwise, as the teaching here implies. Further, the Buddha’s statement here reads as if it were an answer to a question on how to discern which of the many different ascetics were worthy of respect. It seems to me likely that the narrative has become a little confused.
comment_text.mn150:4.4: The idiom samavisamaṁ caranti means “walk roughly in the smooth”, in other words, “conduct themselves badly among the good”, in contrast with those who “walk smoothly in the rough” (caranti visame samaṁ, SN 1.7:3.4, SN 2.6:8.6).
comment_text.mn150:4.15: This is a much higher standard than that implied at MN 142:8.1. However, the context is different: there, it is whether offerings will be fruitful, here it is whether they are truly deserving of respect.

root_text.mn150:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ yena nagaravindaṁ nāma kosalānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ gāmo tadavasari.
root_text.mn150:2.2: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ nagaravindaṁ anuppatto.
root_text.mn150:2.3: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
root_text.mn150:2.4: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
root_text.mn150:2.5: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn150:2.6: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
root_text.mn150:2.7: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī”ti.
root_text.mn150:3.1: Atha kho nagaravindeyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā appekacce bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu; sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Appekacce bhagavato santike nāmagottaṁ sāvetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinne kho nagaravindeyyake brāhmaṇagahapatike bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.mn150:4.1: “Sace vo, gahapatayo, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ puccheyyuṁ:
root_text.mn150:4.2: ‘kathaṁbhūtā, gahapatayo, samaṇabrāhmaṇā na sakkātabbā na garukātabbā na mānetabbā na pūjetabbā’ti?
root_text.mn150:4.3: Evaṁ puṭṭhā tumhe, gahapatayo, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākareyyātha:
root_text.mn150:4.4: ‘ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu avītarāgā avītadosā avītamohā, ajjhattaṁ avūpasantacittā, samavisamaṁ caranti kāyena vācāya manasā, evarūpā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na sakkātabbā na garukātabbā na mānetabbā na pūjetabbā.
root_text.mn150:4.6: Mayampi hi cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu avītarāgā avītadosā avītamohā, ajjhattaṁ avūpasantacittā, samavisamaṁ carāma kāyena vācāya manasā, tesaṁ no samacariyampi hetaṁ uttari apassataṁ.
root_text.mn150:4.7: Tasmā te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā na sakkātabbā na garukātabbā na mānetabbā na pūjetabbā.
root_text.mn150:4.12: manoviññeyyesu dhammesu avītarāgā avītadosā avītamohā, ajjhattaṁ avūpasantacittā, samavisamaṁ caranti kāyena vācāya manasā, evarūpā samaṇabrāhmaṇā na sakkātabbā na garukātabbā na mānetabbā na pūjetabbā.
root_text.mn150:4.14: Mayampi hi manoviññeyyesu dhammesu avītarāgā avītadosā avītamohā, ajjhattaṁ avūpasantacittā, samavisamaṁ carāma kāyena vācāya manasā, tesaṁ no samacariyampi hetaṁ uttari apassataṁ.
root_text.mn150:4.15: Tasmā te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā na sakkātabbā na garukātabbā na mānetabbā na pūjetabbā’ti.
root_text.mn150:4.16: Evaṁ puṭṭhā tumhe, gahapatayo, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākareyyātha.
root_text.mn150:5.1: Sace pana vo, gahapatayo, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ puccheyyuṁ:
root_text.mn150:5.2: ‘kathaṁbhūtā, gahapatayo, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā’ti?

root_text.mn150:5.4: ‘ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu vītarāgā vītadosā vītamohā, ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacittā, samacariyaṁ caranti kāyena vācāya manasā, evarūpā samaṇabrāhmaṇā sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā.
root_text.mn150:5.6: Mayampi hi cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu avītarāgā avītadosā avītamohā, ajjhattaṁ avūpasantacittā, samavisamaṁ carāma kāyena vācāya manasā, tesaṁ no samacariyampi hetaṁ uttari passataṁ.
root_text.mn150:5.7: Tasmā te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā.
root_text.mn150:5.12: manoviññeyyesu dhammesu vītarāgā vītadosā vītamohā, ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacittā, samacariyaṁ caranti kāyena vācāya manasā, evarūpā samaṇabrāhmaṇā sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā.
root_text.mn150:5.14: Mayampi hi manoviññeyyesu dhammesu avītarāgā avītadosā avītamohā ajjhattaṁ avūpasantacittā, samavisamaṁ carāma kāyena vācāya manasā, tesaṁ no samacariyampi hetaṁ uttari passataṁ.
root_text.mn150:5.15: Tasmā te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā’ti.
root_text.mn150:5.16: Evaṁ puṭṭhā tumhe, gahapatayo, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākareyyātha.
root_text.mn150:6.1: Sace pana vo, gahapatayo, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ puccheyyuṁ:
root_text.mn150:6.2: ‘ke panāyasmantānaṁ ākārā, ke anvayā, yena tumhe āyasmanto evaṁ vadetha?
root_text.mn150:6.3: Addhā te āyasmanto vītarāgā vā rāgavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītadosā vā dosavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītamohā vā mohavinayāya vā paṭipannā’ti?
root_text.mn150:6.4: Evaṁ puṭṭhā tumhe, gahapatayo, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākareyyātha:
root_text.mn150:6.5: ‘tathā hi te āyasmanto araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti.
root_text.mn150:6.6: Natthi kho pana tattha tathārūpā cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā ye disvā disvā abhirameyyuṁ, natthi kho pana tattha tathārūpā sotaviññeyyā saddā ye sutvā sutvā abhirameyyuṁ, natthi kho pana tattha tathārūpā ghānaviññeyyā gandhā ye ghāyitvā ghāyitvā abhirameyyuṁ, natthi kho pana tattha tathārūpā jivhāviññeyyā rasā ye sāyitvā sāyitvā abhirameyyuṁ, natthi kho pana tattha tathārūpā kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā ye phusitvā phusitvā abhirameyyuṁ.
root_text.mn150:6.7: Ime kho no, āvuso, ākārā, ime anvayā, yena mayaṁ evaṁ vadema—
root_text.mn150:6.8: addhā te āyasmanto vītarāgā vā rāgavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītadosā vā dosavinayāya vā paṭipannā, vītamohā vā mohavinayāya vā paṭipannā’ti.
root_text.mn150:6.9: Evaṁ puṭṭhā tumhe, gahapatayo, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākareyyāthā”ti.
root_text.mn150:7.1: Evaṁ vutte, nagaravindeyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn150:7.3: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.mn150:7.4: Ete mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn150:7.5: Upāsake no bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṁ gate”ti.

translation_text.mn150:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Nagaravinda.
translation_text.mn150:2.1: The brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda heard,
translation_text.mn150:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Nagaravinda, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn150:2.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn150:2.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn150:2.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn150:2.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn150:3.1: Then the brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. The Buddha said to them:
translation_text.mn150:4.1: “Householders, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:
translation_text.mn150:4.2: ‘What kind of ascetic or brahmin doesn’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration?’
translation_text.mn150:4.4: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are not free of greed, hate, and delusion for sights known by the eye, who are not peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves badly among the good by way of body, speech, and mind. They don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
translation_text.mn150:4.6: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, so we do not see that they have any higher good conduct than us.
translation_text.mn150:4.7: That’s why they don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
translation_text.mn150:4.8: There are ascetics and brahmins who are not free of greed, hate, and delusion for sounds known by the ear …
translation_text.mn150:4.12: ideas known by the mind, who are not peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves badly among the good by way of body, speech, and mind. They don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
translation_text.mn150:4.14: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, so we do not see that they have any higher good conduct than us.
translation_text.mn150:4.15: That’s why they don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.’
translation_text.mn150:4.16: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.
translation_text.mn150:5.1: If wanderers of other religions were to ask you:
translation_text.mn150:5.2: ‘What kind of ascetic or brahmin deserves honor, respect, reverence, and veneration?’
translation_text.mn150:5.4: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are free of greed, hate, and delusion for sights known by the eye, who are peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves well by way of body, speech, and mind. They deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
translation_text.mn150:5.6: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, but we see that they have a higher good conduct than us.
translation_text.mn150:5.7: That’s why they deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
translation_text.mn150:5.8: There are ascetics and brahmins who are free of greed, hate, and delusion for sounds known by the ear …
translation_text.mn150:5.12: ideas known by the mind, who are peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves well by way of body, speech, and mind. They deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
translation_text.mn150:5.14: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, but we see that they have a higher good conduct than us.
translation_text.mn150:5.15: That’s why they deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
translation_text.mn150:5.16: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.
translation_text.mn150:6.1: If wanderers of other religions were to ask you:
translation_text.mn150:6.2: ‘But what reasons and evidence do you have regarding those venerables that justifies saying,
translation_text.mn150:6.3: “Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”?’
translation_text.mn150:6.5: ‘It’s because those venerables frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
translation_text.mn150:6.6: In such places there are no sights known by the eye to see and enjoy, there are no sounds known by the ear to hear and enjoy, no odors known by the nose to smell and enjoy, no flavors known by the tongue to taste and enjoy, and no touches known by the body to feel and enjoy.
translation_text.mn150:6.7: These are the reasons and evidence that you have regarding those venerables that justifies saying,
translation_text.mn150:6.8: “Clearly those venerables are free of greed, hate, and delusion, or practicing to be free of them”.’
translation_text.mn150:6.9: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.”
translation_text.mn150:7.1: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn150:7.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn150:7.4: We go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn150:7.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
